Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Coverage, Capacity, and Connectivity of Wireless Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless sensor networks play an important role in a wide variety of applications such as environment monitoring and battlefield surveillance. The basic function of a wireless sensor network is to monitor its deployed region and transport sensor data to certain designated nodes. Therefore, coverage, capacity, and connectivity are three most fundamental properties for the operation and performance of a wireless sensor network. A deep understanding of these properties and their interrelationship is of great importance for the network planning, algorithm design, and performance of wireless sensor networks.

This project aims to establish a strong theoretical foundation and design practical protocols to provide high performance coverage, capacity, and connectivity in wireless sensor networks. Wireless sensor networks have many unique characteristics differing from other wireless networks, including heterogeneous sensing, communication, and mobility capabilities of sensor nodes, limited infrastructure and power supply, and traffic pattern where data mainly flow from sensors to data sinks rather than between peer nodes. This research integrates the concepts and techniques in wireless communications, stochastic modeling, geometry, and combinatorial optimizations to construct analytical models and develop practical solutions.

The expected outcomes include: (i) fundamental limits of the coverage, capacity, and connectivity under various network scenarios; (ii) efficient algorithms for robust coverage, connectivity, and data transportation; (iii) a test-bed to validate the analytical results and evaluate the performance of algorithms via real experiments. This project also includes a strong educational component that promotes teaching, training, and learning through the active involvement of research students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The basic function of a wireless sensor network (WSN) is to monitor its deployed region and transport sensor data to certain designated nodes. This project investigates the fundamental limits and effective algorithm design to provide high performance coverage, capacity, and connectivity for large-scale wireless sensor networks. 

For coverage, we investigated the impact of different sensor deployment strategies on the coverage of wireless sensor networks and examined the implications on the sensor network design. We obtained the fundamental limit of the barrier coverage under sensor mobility constraint and devised sensor mobility schemes to achieve the limit. We introduced the notion of dynamic coverage resulting from continuous sensor movement, and investigated the effect of sensor mobility and optimal mobility strategies for intrusion detection. For capacity, we established the achievable scaling laws on the secure throughput capacity that can be realized in a large random wireless network in the presence of eavesdroppers of unknown location. We considered the capacity of cache enabled content distribution wireless ad hoc networks, and established the scaling laws of the capacity for two fundamental content access schemes, namely the nearest caching node scheme and transparent en-route caching scheme. For connectivity, we considered the problem of securely delivering a message from the source to the destination and derived achievable network connectivity results on the number of eavesdropper nodes that can be tolerated by the network. 

The results we obtained in this project have deepened our understanding on the fundamental limits and performance bounds of large-scale wireless sensor networks. The research also designs efficient algorithms for the deployment, self-organization of wireless sensor networks for secure, high-performance coverage, data transfer, and robust connectivity. These research results have been published in premier computer networking conferences and journals such as IEEE Infocom, ACM Mobihoc, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, and IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems. 

The PI has integrated the research with education activities. In a graduate-level course (91.564: Data Communications II), the PI has developed and introduced a strong wireless networking component in the course. The PI has also introduced mobile computing and participatory sensing to in his teaching using the smart phone based Microsoft Project Hawaii platform. Students were very excited about the opportunity to use the advanced mobile cloud technologies, and learned a great amount on the principles and practice of wireless networking and mobile computing through the smart phone application developments.

The PI has been very active in outreach activities. He has given numerous demonstrations related to wireless networking, novel sensory approach for public health monitoring, and smart phone based participatory sensing to local high school students. He has also demonstrated the use of mobile and medical sensing technologies to improve healthcare monitoring for remote and underserved areas in Peru.
